I don't 100% know the answer to your first question, but it's a bit vague for me too. The logistics should be the same, you just apply online and submit the same materials as those coming in with their Bachelor's... not sure if that's helpful? But regarding the rest:

  • Generally, the most important thing the admissions committee wants to see is evidence of your research ability, which in general comes across via a rec letter from another researcher whose opinion they can gauge & ideally trust.
  • You want at least one great letter talking about your research experience. What's in the the rest is less crucial; I think those can just be general recommendation letters, and they won't really matter much. (Just make sure the rest don't suggest negative things about you.) For that one-great-letter though, my impression is most industry letters won't be able to do that, unless it's by (say) a researcher in industry.
  • I would guess (though don't know) that if you apply after industry, they might want to see more recent research experience from you, so your paper from undergrad might carry less weight as time goes on. But you should confirm this with someone who's more knowledgeable about this.
  • Don't forget it's possible to apply and defer your admission for a year in many schools. I think usually you want to only bring this up after you're admitted, but you should chat with some people who know more about this if 1 year is a similar timeline to what you'd consider.
  • To get a rec letter, just go up to your PI (or email, especially given the current situation) and (nicely, but no need to be over the top) ask if they'd be willing to write you a rec letter for grad school. The exact phrasing ("willing" or "able"? "strong letter" or just "letter"? etc.) isn't worth worrying about IMO, though I'm sure some will beg to differ... it's something you can debate for all eternity, and my phrasing might not be optimal, but unless you have some legit reason to think they would be willing to write you a weak letter but not a strong one, I wouldn't care about it.

children.subject:
Existence is one thing, whereas finding and obtaining these positions is another. I know non-PhDs in traditional PhD rules do exist, but as you can imagine it can be harder to get these roles without a PhD, and I'm sure there are also places that will stick to their rules and won't hire non-PhDs, period. I don't really know if there's a blanket statement that can be made here. As a general rule, though, I'd say if you have an appropriate background/evidence showing you can do quality research, and if it looks like the only reason you didn't get a PhD is that you just never bothered going down that path, then you'd have a shot at some of these positions. The people to talk to more about this are probably your PI and recruiters, though. Your faculty likely have relevant connections in industry, and recruiters would be able to give you more company-specific information. It's really hard to make a blanket statement here.

As for AI/ML vs. other stuff... well ML is the hot new area that's been getting the most funding, so naturally it gets the most focus. Now "SysML" has become a thing (basically, suddenly ML folks who previously didn't care for systems suddenly got the idea of building better systems for ML work) so you might see some systems-y work too. How much actual research is involved on the systems side is hard for me to say; I don't really know. Again, asking faculty in your research area of interest might not be a bad idea to get an idea of how to continue research in related areas in industry.

re: specifically research jobs in ai / ml for bachelor's, it's certainly possible (look for "research engineer" or "ml engineer" or "dl engineer" positions) but these roles are extremely specific to each company and they usually require additional work to obtain.

to give an example, a research engineer at facebook ai research can do fundamental research, and often they have phd's and are essentially research scientists except for internal bureaucratic reasons. however, a machine learning engineer at many companies is responsible for training, validating, and deploying models, rather than doing any kind of research. you really have to know the company, it's not like "software engineer" where the role is effectively the same across most companies, even between, say, a big N (google / fb / msft / amzn), a large """startup""" (airbnb / uber / lyft) and a small startup.

generally, the more applied the research is (e.g. vision is more applications-focused than fundamental ML), the more research-y the role can be for bachelors; and the smaller the company is, the more flexibility they have in the role.

the people who get more research-y roles out of bachelors usually have done research for a while so they have papers / research connects, or they interned at somewhere more than once so they can navigate the internal gatekeepers.

not totally on topic but im sure lots of ppl are wondering about GP's question but for ai / ml

@Mehrdad thanks for your response -- super helpful! Just wondering -- do you know if are there industry postbac research jobs in CS? Most of the research stuff I found was focused towards AI/ML PhD's :(
to save letters explore 'interfolio', a dossier service

+1 to student answer

to be upfront you are unlikely to get a detailed answer from grad admissions / professor. profs usually don't lurk here (exceptions are Professor Sahai, some others) and this question requires a lot of context to answer well (e.g. r/e at brain can get a good letter from quoc but some ml plumber at jp morgan is not gonna get a reputable letter). to get a good answer, go to office hours (oops, those don't exist this semester) and ask. literally any prof whose research you think is cool, go to their grad class oh since nobody goes to oh.

also, talk to grad students - much easier to get their time + they have applied more recently. professors who haven't sat on admissions recently (past 1-3 years) are surprisingly uninformed about things in the fields that have heated up recently


but very briefly -

(1) you just apply like normal, it's not different. if you don't know how applying to phds work there are lots of guides on the internet and u need to take the initiative to find them. but this is a classic - https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~harchol/gradschooltalk.pdf and so is - http://www.pgbovine.net/PhD-application-tips.htm as is http://www.pgbovine.net/grad-school-app-tips.htm. you always have to adjust a little bit for differences over time, like ai / ml is really hard to get in, but usually the big picture applies. but yeah this question is so basic that you need to do a lot of shoe leather googling

(2) ask. smth like "Would you be willing to write me a letter of recommendation for phd programs?". it's important that you always give them a way to say no and ask very politely. but, if you have done research with somebody and you didn't egregiously mess up, it's strongly expected that they write you a letter. how good it is, not guaranteed.

(3) see (1). it's basically the same. your letters will "decay" in value - past 1-2 years they start to become less reputable and after like 3-4 years they're effectively useless.

(4) i'm not qualified to speak about systems-y things, but broadly speaking work experience counts for exactly nil. it says nothing about your *research ability*, and that's all that matters for top programs.

(5) correct (may be different for systems). the reason why is threefold - first, they can't speak about your research ability, which is all that matters, since you didn't do research with them. second, the people reading the letter don't know them, so they aren't fully credible. for all the person reading knows, they're a family friend you got to write you a letter. and third, and most importantly, they're not *calibrated*. a renowned professor will be able to say, "Anonymous Helix is the best student I've had in 5 years. The last student who was like Anonymous Helix went to X school and became a professor. I think that Anonymous Helix has a bright future and I would be happy to work with Anonymous Helix in my own research group." your manager in industry cannot say anything remotely similar.

why should you trust me about this? i really hope you don't take everything i say at face value and instead make the effort to google everything i've said and talk to seniors and grad students, because you should do that anyway :-)

So I'm currently a junior and interested in the systems part of CS (distributed systems and security specifically). I have a few semesters of research experience and even a middle author publication, although my GPA leaves a bit to be desired.

I'm definitely interested in applying for PhD programs, but not 100% sure if I really want to do a PhD. I want to work for a few years before applying (save up money, more maturity, see what industry is like, etc).

My questions are the following:
(1) What are the logistics of applying to PhD after working?
(2) How do I get/save recommendation letters from my current research advisors?
(3) How does applying for PhD after working differ from applying straight out of BS?
(4) How do admissions committees evaluate work experience-- specifically some systems-y SWE job which is related to my field of interest?
(5) Letters from managers in industry are usually not helpful, right?


I would much appreciate if a professor/grad admissions officer would be able to answer this question as well.

Thanks so much!
